stem: The nurse is educating a client on various diabetes treatments. Match each medication with its primary dietary instruction.

columns.text: Take with the first bite of each main meal.
Take with meals to reduce GI upset (Nausea/Diarrhea).

rationale.correct: Medication timing determines efficacy and safety. (r1) Rapid insulin needs food fast to prevent crashes. (r2) Regular insulin has a longer onset. (r3) Acarbose works on the food *in* the gut, so it must be present with the first bite. (r4) Metformin's main side effect is GI distress, which is minimized by food.
rationale.incorrect: Taking Acarbose without food is useless as it works by slowing carbohydrate absorption in the small intestine.
clinicalPearls: If a client on acarbose experiences hypoglycemia, you must treat it with GLUCOSE (tabs/gel), not sucrose (cane sugar/juice), because acarbose blocks sucrose absorption.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that Acarbose is the only one typically specified as 'First Bite.' Most others are 'With' or 'Before' meals.

mnemonic.title: A-B-C-D
mnemonic.expansion: Acarbose (At-the-bite), Biguanide/Metformin (Buffer with food), C-insulin (Careful timing), Delivery ( tray in room).

reviewUnits.heading: Oral Antidiabetics and Insulin
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must coordinate care with dietary services. For clients who are NPO (nothing by mouth), many of these medications must be held or adjusted to prevent dangerous hypoglycemia.
